section.title: Logging using RLTP
section.para: The syslog-ng application can send and receive log messages in a reliable way over the TCP transport layer using the Reliable Log Transfer Protocol (RLTP). RLTP is a new transport protocol that prevents message loss during connection breaks. The transport is used between syslog-ng and syslog-ng and it interoperates with the flow control and reliable disk-buffer mechanisms, thus providing the best loss-less environment. It detects the last received message on the receiving end and then starts resending messages from that point. Therefore, messages are not duplicated at the receiving end in case of a connection break (however, in failover mode this is not completely ensured). It also allows the negotiation of using TLS with a single source driver (for example negotiation at the beginning of the connection).

warning.para: If you use RLTP together with non-reliable disk-buffer, it is possible to lose logs. When sending logs through a relay that is using a non-reliable disk-buffer, it is possible to lose logs in case of relay crash.
When sending logs through a relay that is using a non-reliable disk-buffer, it is possible that logs are duplicated in case of relay crash or stopping the relay.

section.para: It is used on top of TCP, and can use STARTTLS for encryption. RLTP supports IPv4 and IPv6 addresses. Inside the RLTP message, the format can be RFC3164 (BSD syslog) or RFC5424 (IETF syslog). The default port of RLTP is 35514.
RLTP can be added to the configuration like a transport protocol within the syslog() driver and the network() driver.

simplesect.title: message_acknowledgement_timeout()
simplesect.para: Description: After not receiving any reply to the messages in the given timeframe, syslog-ng terminates the connection with the other side

simplesect.title: response_timeout()
simplesect.para: Description: After not receiving any message in the given timeframe, syslog-ng terminates the connection with the other side

simplesect.title: tls_required()
simplesect.para: Description: Determines whether STARTTLS is to be used during communication. If the option is set to yes or optional, setting up tls() context is required. This option can be used both on client and server side, however, server side is the decisive one (except if one of them is set to optional in which case the other side is the decisive one). For example, if on server side tls_required(yes) and on client side tls_required(no), the connection is dropped.

example.title: RLTP with optional TLS encryption
example.para: For both source and destination sides, tls_required is set to optional, therefore they will communicate through TLS. For the server (source side) the response_timeout and message_acknowledgement_timeout settings ensure that the connection is terminated if no messages are received in the set timeframes. For the client (destination side), the reliable disk-buffer is set to yes, to prevent data loss.

example.title: RLTP with tls_required()
example.para: The source and the destination would communicate through the network protocol, but since tls_required is set to yes on the server side and no on the client side, the connection is terminated by the server.
